questions.question:
Question 1: A junior radiologist performing a fetal doppler follows the direction of the flow of oxygenated 
blood from the placenta to the fetus to examine the fetal circulatory vessels. The sequence 
that he would follow is:

options.a: Umbilical artery  inferior vena cava  ductus venosus  right atrium  left atrium
options.b: Umbilical artery  superior vena cava  right atrium  ductus arteriosus  left atrium
options.c: Umbilical vein  ductus venosus  inferior vena cava  right atrium  left atrium
options.d: Umbilical vein  ductus arteriosus  superior vena cava  right atrium  left atrium

questions.explanation:
The sequence of oxygenated blood flow from the placenta to the fetal heart is umbilical vein 
ductus venosus  inferior venacava  right atrium  left atrium.

questions.question:
Question 2: Oxygenated blood is carried to the fetus by  
.
questions.explanation:
Oxygenated blood is carried to the fetus by the umbilical vein. The umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus into the inferior vena cava. Thus, the 
inferior vena cava, which also carries blood from hepatic veins, kidneys, and from lower 
extremities carries a mixture of deoxygenated and oxygenated blood. So, the highest percentage of 
oxygen in the fetal circulation is in the umbilical vein, followed by the inferior vena cava. The umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta for oxygenation. Note: In the umbilical cord, there are a pair of umbilical arteries and a single umbilical vein. Mnemonic: AVA- artery –vein- artery(2 arteries and a single vein).

questions.question:
Question 3: A final year student is asked to give a seminar on 'fetal circulation.' Which among the 
following statement told by him in the seminar is likely to be false?

options.a: Heart receives blood with high oxygen saturation
options.b: Pressure in right and left ventricles are equal
options.c: Liver receives blood with low oxygen saturation compared to the brain
options.d: Blood in inferior venacava has lower oxygen concentration compared to superior venacava

questions.explanation:
Blood in the inferior vena cava has a higher oxygen concentration compared to the superior vena 
cava. 451 
Sold by @itachibot The superior vena cava carries the deoxygenated blood from the upper part of the body to the 
right atrium. The highly oxygenated blood is carried to the fetus from the placenta via 
the umbilical vein with 50% of the umbilical venous blood entering the hepatic circulation and the 
rest bypassing the liver and joining the inferior vena cava (IVC) via the ductus venosus. Hence, the 
blood in the inferior vena cava has a higher oxygen concentration compared to the superior vena 
cava. Also, relatively a larger percentage of oxygen-rich blood is perfused to the brain. Pressures in both the right and left ventricles are equal in a developing fetus. The upper part of 
the body is perfused exclusively by the left ventricle while the lower extremities are perfused by 
the right ventricle.

questions.question:
Question 4: The total fetal cardiac output at term is estimated to be 
 per minute.
questions.explanation:
The total fetal cardiac output at term is approximately 450 mL/kg/min. Approximately 65% of descending aortic blood flow returns to the placenta, and hence, only the 
remaining 35% perfuses the fetal organs and tissues. The clinical relevance of this 65% blood flow being directed to the placenta comes in the context 
of delayed cord clamping vs early cord clamping after delivery. Delayed cord clamping entails the 
umbilical cord is clamped more than one minute after the birth or when cord pulsation has 
ceased. This delayed clamping allows the blood flow between the placenta and neonate to 
continue and helps improve the iron status in the infant.

questions.question:
Question 5: During the evaluation of a newborn, you hear a continuous machinery murmur. Where would 
the structure responsible for the murmur ideally be located?

options.a: Just proximal to the left common carotid
options.b: Just distal to the left subclavian
options.c: Just distal to the left common carotid
options.d: Just proximal to the left subclavian

questions.explanation:
Continuous machinery murmur in a newborn is characteristic of Patent ductus arteriosus. Most 
commonly, the ductus arteriosus is just distal to the left subclavian artery and the ductus enters 
the pulmonary artery at its bifurcation. The image attached below shows the relations of ductus arteriosus. 452 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: You assist the delivery of a 3.1 kg healthy term neonate by spontaneous vaginal delivery. As 
the baby transitions from the fetal circulation, what is the sequence of functional closure of 
the following structures?

options.a: Ductus venosus --> Foramen ovale --> Ductus arteriosus
options.b: Ductus arteriosus --> Foramen ovale --> Ductus venosus
options.c: Ductus venosus --> Ductus arteriosus --> Foramen ovale
options.d: Ductus arteriosus --> Ductus venosus --> Foramen ovale

questions.explanation:
Functional closure of the fetal circulatory adjustments occurs in the following sequence: Ductus 
venosus --> Foramen ovale --> Ductus arteriosus Fetal circulatory adjustment 
Functional closure 
Anatomical closu 
re 7 days Ductus venosus 
After removal of the placenta from fetal circulatory unit Foramen ovale 
At birth - after breathing is in

questions.question:
Question 7: During the examination of a neonate with documented hearing defects and bilateral zonular 
cataracts, you hear a continuous machinery murmur. The mother gives a history of viral 
exanthem during the first trimester of the pregnancy. By when should the underlying 
defective channel that is responsible for the murmur anatomically close?
questions.explanation:
The given vignette is suggestive of Patent ductus arteriosus in a child with congenital rubella 
syndrome. The anatomical closure of the ductus arteriosus occurs at 10-21 days. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with 
rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS). PDA presents with a continuous machinery 
murmur. Triad of congenital rubella syndrome • Sensorineural deafness • Congenital heart defects – MC is PDA • Cataracts Classical rubella syndrome consists of: • Ocular defects: Congenital cataract, salt and pepper 
chorioretinopathy, microphthalmos, Glaucoma, and anterior uveitis • Ear defects: Sensorineural hearing loss due to destruction of organ of Corti • Heart defects: Patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary stenosis, and ventricular septal defects 453 
Sold by @itachibot Fetal circulatory adjustment 
Functional closure 
Anatomical closu 
re 7 days Ductus venosus 
After removal of the placenta from fetal circulatory unit Foramen ovale 
At birth - after breathing is in 
itiated Months to years Ductus arteriosus 
10–15 hours 
10–21 days

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is the main factor for the ductal closure postnatally?

options.a: Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2)

questions.explanation:
Oxygen is the most important factor controlling ductal closure. 454 
Sold by @itachibot Gestational age also appears to play an important role; the ductus of a premature infant is less 
responsive to oxygen, even though its musculature is developed. Hence, patent ductus arteriosus 
(PDA) is more common in premature infants. The fetal circulatory adjustments after birth are given below: The patency of ductus arteriosus may either provide an alternative route for blood to bypass 
congenital defects such as pulmonary atresia or coarctation of the aorta. Therapeutic medications can be used to either maintain the patency (prostaglandin E1) or 
promote closure (indomethacin). Drugs like indomethacin are not recommended during the third 
trimester of pregnancy. Functional closure 
Anatomical closu 
re Ductus venosus 
After removal of the placenta 
7 days Foramen ovale

questions.question:
Question 9: A newborn infant develops respiratory distress 2 days after birth. On examination, she is 
mottled and has weak upper extremity pulses and absent femoral pulses. Investigations 
reveal the coarctation of the aorta. Which of the following drugs can you use to keep the 
ductus open medically before surgical repair?
questions.explanation:
Alprostadil, a prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analogue, can be used to keep the ductus open medically in 
the coarctation of the aorta. The ductus arteriosus (the fetal connection between the pulmonary artery and the descending 
aorta) is functionally closed at 10-15hrs after birth and anatomically closed at 10-21 days after 
birth. Survival of newborns with certain heart lesions such as coarctation of the aorta, hypoplastic left 
heart syndrome and transposition of great vessels depends on the patency of ductus arteriosus. 
Closure of PDA in such conditions can lead to hypoperfusion, severe hypoxia and cyanosis. PGE1 is a potent and specific relaxant of ductal smooth muscle. PGE1 analogues like alprostadil, 
misoprost and rioprostil can be used to keep the ductus open and support systemic blood supply. In patent ductus arteriosus, the ductus is closed medically by NSAIDS (which inhibit 
prostaglandin synthesis) like ibuprofen trometamol/ ibuprofen lysine and indomethacin. 
Morphine can be used to manage respiratory distress but rarely preferred in a neonate.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 23-year-old woman with G2P1 and an ‘h-negative pregnancy gave birth to a baby with an 
‘h-positive blood group. The direct Coomb's test is positive. Cord blood bilirubin level is 
more than 4 mg/dL. The team plans for an isovolumetric and simultaneous double set up 
exchange transfusion. But the preferred vessel seems obliterated. This obliterated fibrotic 
vessel would now be called as?
questions.explanation:
The umbilical vein is the preferred vessel for an isovolumetric and simultaneous double set up 
exchange transfusion. The obliterated remnant of the umbilical vein is the Ligamentum teres. The vessels that are occluded soon after birth are in due course replaced by fibrous tissue and 
forms the following ligaments: 455 
Sold by @itachibot The median umbilical ligament or Xander's ligament represents the remnant of the embryonic 
urachus. The lateral umbilical ligaments are folds of the peritoneum over the inferior epigastric arteries. Note: Cord blood bilirubin level more than 4 mg/dL is an indication for change transfusion in a neonate. Fetal structure 
Adult structure Foramen ovale 
Fossa ovalis Umbilical vein 
Ligamentum teres Ductus venosus 
Ligamentum venosum Medial umbilical ligament 
s Umbilical arterie 
s Ductus arteriosu 
s Ligamentum arteriosum 456
